fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: The estimated future volume of radioactive waste being accumulated in Britain's nuclear sites is 20m cubic metres and not, as we said in yesterday's front page lead story, 20,000m cubic metres (Ministers break promises over nuclear waste, page 1). We said that the Israeli embassy in Washington had "refuted" an espionage allegation when we meant, as the embassy statement made clear, that it had been denied (FBI fears Israel has Pentagon spy, page 17, August 28). To refute is to provide proof that something is incorrect. Calypso was the sea nymph who fell in love with Odysseus and kept him for seven years, promising him immortality and eternal youth if he would stay with her. In yesterday's radio review we mistakenly said it was Cyclops, the one-eyed giant (An epic undertaking, G2, page 20). The work called Grandmaster Bush, being displayed at the Experimental Party Disinformation Centre and referred to in the report headlined Fortress New York takes post-9/11 play to its heart (page 11, August 28), is by Rick Silva and not, as we said, by Mark Amerika. · It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number.
